stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the Wild West level, implementing a bulletin board asset from Zeina, designing a new bank employee Koopa NPC from scratch, and problem-solving the puzzle for entering a secret Monty Mole area. A major focus is also testing and discussing his new, completely rewritten collision system for Mario.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is in the process of completely rewriting the game's collision system from scratch to be more stable and robust than the original SM64 system, using a binary search and raycast method.
development_findings.quote: I had an idea yesterday to just rewrite Mario's collision entirely. What you're seeing right now is the rewritten collision.

development_findings.summary: The new spin jump animation was deliberately based on Mario's animation from Super Smash Bros. Melee to feel authentic to the era, replacing a previous 'twirl' animation Kaze disliked.
development_findings.quote: The closest you have to an official version of the spin jump from 1996 is Mario's Down-B from Smash Melee. So, I went with that one.

development_findings.summary: A new engine feature is a dynamic dialogue box that automatically resizes to fit the length of the text, which Kaze considers a useful quality-of-life improvement for development and translation.
The project is currently at Course 12 of a planned 15, with about 3.5 levels remaining to be built.
A puzzle involving a breakable rock will require the bomb cap, a deliberate choice to make use of an underutilized power-up from the original game.
development_findings.quote: The bomb cap for once the caps are so underused. Oh, I like the bomb cap idea. Maybe we should use the bomb cap.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implements custom rendering settings for objects, like 'fog-shaded decals', to correctly integrate them into the N64's lighting and fog system, showing a deep technical understanding of the engine.
The game will not feature traditional 100-coin stars; they have been replaced with a system of collecting Yoshi coins.
development_findings.quote: Yoshi coins... replace the 100 coin stars.

development_findings.summary: Kaze watched the TV show 'Westworld' as research and preparation for designing the Wild West level.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the original Mario 64's strength is its movement, not its level design, which he finds often lacks a sense of place or 'placeness'.
context_findings.quote: I don't think Mario 64 is that great either, except for the movement design. Like the level design itself is not great, but the movement is like awesome. So that's the part I want to change.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy is that not all levels should feel like they were created for Mario; many should feel like pre-existing worlds that Mario is simply visiting.
context_findings.quote: We want a lot of them to feel more like they are there and Mario is experiencing them.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that using assets from external sources (like Google) is acceptable within the context of ROM hacking.
context_findings.quote: It'd be hypocritical for us to like hack roms and then pretend like it's completely wrong to take assets.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions he moved to North America from his home country, partially for financial reasons.
context_findings.quote: I moved to North America. Had to run away from all the taxes, you know.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is self-aware of his sometimes unusual way of explaining concepts, describing it as a vibe that resonates with people some of the time.
context_findings.quote: I say a lot of really weird things... But then 1 out of 10 times, it just hits you and you're like, yeah, this man is speaking to my soul. That's what I'm going for here.

biobak.summary: Kaze identifies Biobak as a key contributor who helps a lot with the hack's development.
Kaze noted that a new dynamic text box feature he implemented will be very helpful for Biobak if he chooses to translate the game.

badub.summary: Baduk is creating a lot of the music for the project. Kaze defers questions about a potential soundtrack release to him.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the 3D model and textures for the bulletin board asset.
Zeina created the new spin jump animation, which Kaze then polished.
Zeina contributes artistic ideas during development, such as suggesting a tie for the bank Koopa and providing textures for his eyes.
Kaze and Zeina have a playful dynamic where they banter and disagree on creative decisions, with Kaze humorously suggesting his projects would fail if he always listened to her.
zeina.quote: He might crush their stem, right? That's what he does in the original. If I listened to Zeina more, I would be fucked.

key_stories.title: The Accidental Discovery Problem
key_stories.summary: Kaze wrestled with how to design the entrance to a secret area. He wanted players to solve a mystery, not just stumble upon a fake-looking wall. After debating several ideas, he settled on a breakable rock requiring a specific power-up to ensure the discovery feels earned.
key_stories.challenge: The entrance to a secret Monty Mole sub-level needed to be discovered through deliberate puzzle-solving, not by accident. A simple hole in the wall felt uninspired.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered a fake cardboard cutout boulder but rejected it as too obvious. He then considered a cloth covering but deemed the required physics too complex for the N64. He settled on the breakable rock as the best balance of puzzle design and technical feasibility.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to use a visibly cracked but solid-looking boulder that can only be destroyed with the bomb cap. This solution requires the player to connect NPC hints with a specific gameplay mechanic, making the discovery a rewarding action.
key_stories.key_quote: I want players to be like there's a bank robbery. There is moles going around here. Let's go into the tunnel. I don't want them to be like, oh look this looks fake. Let's punch it.

key_stories.title: Rewriting the Laws of Physics
key_stories.summary: Frustrated with the core physics of Mario 64, Kaze took on the monumental task of rewriting the game's collision detection from the ground up. He is developing a new, hybrid system to provide a stable and reliable platform for the game's movement, a core focus of his design philosophy.
key_stories.challenge: The standard Mario 64 collision system is notoriously buggy, leading to unwanted wall clips and unstable physics. Previous attempts to fix it with raycasting introduced new problems.
key_stories.process: Unhappy with the limitations and bugs of the original SM64 'step function' and his previous raycast-based solution, Kaze decided to completely discard the old code. He started building a new system the day before the stream, based on a binary search for the largest viable step, augmented with raycasts and verifications.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze has created a new, faster, and more robust collision system from scratch. While still a work-in-progress with some bugs, it's a fundamental architectural change intended to make the game's movement significantly more reliable than any other SM64 project.
key_stories.key_quote: Once my new collision system is done, dude, this game will be so nice collision-wise, I think. Much better than any other Mario 64 thing.

key_stories.title: Creating the Banker Koopa
key_stories.summary: Kaze's process for creating a bank employee Koopa shows his blend of research, artistic iteration, and technical problem-solving. From looking up references to sculpting a beard and implementing ideas from Zeina, the creation of this single NPC encapsulates the team's micro-level creative workflow.
key_stories.challenge: A new Koopa NPC needed to be designed to look like a stereotypical Wild West bank employee, a character archetype with few clear visual references.
key_stories.process: Kaze began by researching visuals online and using ChatGPT for ideas. He then went through an iterative modeling process in Blender, experimenting with baldness, sideburns, and beards. He solved the technical challenge of rendering a beard by using a separate mesh with a wood texture to imply hair strands. Zeina contributed ideas like the tie and provided the eye textures.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze, with artistic input from Zeina, created a unique 'old man' Koopa character with a distinct beard, glasses, and a tie. The final character is a result of creative iteration, technical problem-solving, and collaborative input.
key_stories.key_quote: Being bald in a video game is not about whether you have hair, it's about the vibe.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that the default 'environment' render setting on objects causes bugs and that he had to fix many instances of it in 'the ship level'.
questions: Can you describe the specific visual bugs that this rendering issue caused in the ship level?
What is the technical reason this default setting is problematic on the N64?
How did solving those problems inform your general rendering pipeline for new assets in the game?

open_questions.context: Zeina provides finished assets like animations and models. While we see Kaze implement them, her own creative process and the collaborative steps before the hand-off are not shown.
questions: Can you walk us through your process for creating an asset like the bulletin board, from the initial idea to the final model?
How much creative freedom do you have versus working from a specific concept from Kaze?
What's the back-and-forth process like? How do you and Kaze iterate on a design together?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that Badub creates a lot of music for the hack, but the process of how the music is conceptualized and integrated is not discussed.
questions: How do you communicate the 'vibe' or 'placeness' of a level to Badub?
Do you provide him with gameplay footage, concept art, or just a description to compose to?
Can you give an example of how a piece of music from Badub changed or enhanced your vision for a level?

open_questions.context: Kaze floated 'Rainbow Reef' as a surreal idea for the final course (Course 15) but also mentioned he was not set on it and was open to other ideas.
questions: What was the core concept behind 'Rainbow Reef' and its parallel to Rainbow Road?
What makes a level idea feel strong enough to commit to, versus one that remains flexible?
How much does the immediate feedback from the stream chat influence your decision to stick with or abandon a high-level concept like this?

open_questions.topic: Technical Deep Dive on New Collision System
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions his new collision system is a complete rewrite. He gives a high-level overview but the specific trade-offs and challenges are complex.
questions: You mentioned the new system is faster. What trade-offs, if any, did you have to make to achieve that speed?
What was the most difficult bug you've had to solve in the new system so far?
Why was it so important to you personally to build this from scratch rather than continue patching the existing SM64 code?
